Replies.Reply: My God, it's hot. I stepped out of the shower and stared sweating again.
That's a shame.
I'm leaving.
I go on duty at Miami Airport at seven.
I wouldn't mind having breakfast...
You've had your fun. You're spent.
I'll just slip into my uniform here and slip away.
Hey, I don't mind. I'm leaving.
Hey... hey...
... don't wrinkle it!
The Seawater Inn. My family used to eat dinner there twenty-five years ago. Now somebody's torched it to clear the lot.
Probably one of my clients.
It's four a.m.
My history's burning up out here.
Where's your hat?
'You're spent.' Where'd you hear that?
Judge Costanza, perhaps when I've presented all --
You would look favorably on that?
I'll talk to him.
Thank you, Your Honor.
My defense was evolving. You guys got scared. Costanza doesn't like me. What'd I do to him?
Maybe Costanza was in on it.   That's why he was mad.
He's pretty good, that's the weird part.
No.   Do I want to?
That must have been Mrs. Block's idea, some kind of punishment.
Stella, this is beneath even you.
Mrs. Singer, I would have gladly come to the house.
Don't worry about it. I'll find you a doctor who's more understanding.
How well I know. We'll sue those reckless bastards dry. Excuse my language.
You can stand here with me if you want, but you'll have to agree not to talk about the heat.
Meaning what?
What?
And how, happy is that?
What else you like -- Ugly?   Lazy?
Some. If they haven't been around much.
How 'bout I buy you a drink?
I'll buy him one too.
My favorite kind. We'll drink to him.
I'm liking him better all the time.
What kind?
Make it two.
You're not staying in Miranda Beach.
Pinehaven. You're staying up in Pinehaven, on the waterway.
You have a house.
You look like Pinehaven.
Well tended.
Me? I need tending. I need someone to take care of me. Rub my tired muscles. Smooth out my sheets.
I just need it for tonight.
Matty.    I like it. Right over your heart.
I asked you not to talk about the heat.
Right away.    I'll even wipe it off for you.
I know you.
What about them?
Do I remind you of hot air?
Bourbon, any kind, on the rocks.
Another?
I'm no yokel. Why, I was all the way to Miami once.
I'm not that eager.
Ned Racine.
Are you all right?
Maybe you need a tune-up.
I don't talk that way.
This is the only joint in Pinehaven.
You seemed like a woman with all the vices.
What'd I do?
You must come here a lot.
Maybe you should drink at home.
Maybe you shouldn't dress like that.
You shouldn't wear that body.
I know that sometimes the shit comes down SO heavy I feel like I should wear a hat.
I'll take you.
I'll follow you. I want to see the chimes.
I want to hear them.
I'm not looking for trouble.
I don't know who we're going to fool.
Lady, you must be some kind of crazy!
Jesus.
Just like my place.
No help?
You're not nervous alone?
You do have chimes.
What's that?
No, out there.
What is in there?
I just got here.
You didn't bring me here to see your wind chimes.
No.     not very often.
I don't think you want me to go.
There's nothing to be afraid of.
You're not so tough after all, are you?
That's right... that's right.
I like this place. It's got a nice feel.
So it could use a better mattress.
Hey, gimme a break here.    It takes a little while.
It takes me a good thirty seconds.
Jesus, I think you're right --
-- you better be on the bottom.
Wow!   No, I must object --
Enough.
What are you doing?
You're afraid of your maid?
This is an interesting interpretation.
Hey, lady, wanna make love?
I'm sorry.
I feel like a jerk.
I'm an idiot. Nice to meet you.
It's unusual.   We're famous for our cool breezes.
I didn't see her car. I'm sorry.    I got to be more careful.
You know, this has never been one of my pleasures. Car. I considered the time I spent making it --
-- like this ... penance for some sin.
I never knew. Maybe worshipping women instead of God. But it never did anything for me.
No.
You're killing me.
Come on! It's been three days.      I want to see you --
I'm going.   I'm going.
I'm here.
What do you take me for?
You think I'm a kid?
Listen!
I love that sound.
Is that all you ever think about?
Hey!   I'm kidding.
You look terrible. Don't you sleep?
What do you mean, I been around.
Oscar.
There's nothing to tell.   I lead a lonely life.
There you are.
How's the cop business, Oscar?
Hell, no. Someday -- Deputy County Prosecutor.
Hi, Glenda.
I do. I want you with me.
It is conceivable I'll make a buck someday.
Anyway, you'll come out all right.
Yeah.    He's ripe.
What?
How is it?
The truth? I wish you were going to be loaded. Does it matter? No. No.
I want to see.
Nope, Small weekend. Tiny little weekend.
Beverly, do yourself a big favor and forget it.
Whatever you're thinking.
Yeah.
Did you tell him?
Okay, I'm coming.
How do you know?
How'd he get so fat?
I wonder what they call themselves.
The Breakers? I thought Hermie Fisher owned that land.
Why?
No.    I don't.
What is it, Matty? Tell me exactly what frightens you.
That's where we're at, isn't it, Matty?
That's what we're both thinking --
Don't let it scare you. Because he's not gonna die. There's nothing wrong with him, is there? There's no reason to think he's gonna die, is there?
That's right. So we might as well forget about it, It's not gonna just happen to make things nice for us...
Maybe that's a smart way to be now, Matty. Maybe we both should be.
The only thing wrong with your husband right now... is us.
Well, well.   Hello to you --
Ned.
That hasn't changed, has it?
I can understand that.    It's a terrific place.
I was just going to grab a bite.
No. Thanks very much, but I don't want to interfere with --
Is that right?
F. S. U.
I can afford to send my shirts out.
That's all right. I don't like it much.
Do you?
What is it, exactly?
You don't have to be specific.
Yeah?   Around here?
Is that right?
A lovely lady.
That's understanding.
I'm not sure. You mean, lay the groundwork? Earn it?
Yeah. I know that kind of guy. I can't stand that. It makes me sick.
I'm not like that.
Jesus!    Did Beverly see you?
Angry? I'm not angry -- How'd you get in?
I know.
Yes, that's right. You can't call.
You did good.
You've called my apartment from the house.
No?   Those two times --
That's good. We have to be careful about the phones now.
We could account for a couple calls.
Because we're going to kill him.    We both know that.
That's what you want, isn't it? We knew it was coming. It's the only way we can get everything we want, isn't it?
The man's gonna die for no reason but we want him dead.
He doesn't deserve it. Let's not ever say that. We're doing it for us. And you're going to inherit half of everything he owns. That's what the will says, right?
That's it then. We're gonna kill him. And I think I know how.
Yeah, it's real all right, and if we're not careful, it's gonna be the last real thing we do.
I know where he is. It's not far from here. I don't want you with me.
That's it?
Just regular gasoline?
What?
I don't care about that.
That's all there is to it?
Sorry.
Thanks.
That's the way it is.       There's nothing we can do about it.
No.   Forget it.
Listen to me, Matty. Nothing strange can happen in his life right now, not one thing out of the ordinary.
Okay.   Gotta go.
I'm just going for a ride.   I wish it was all this dangerous.
And?
And?
We won't talk again after     I leave here tonight. I'll be in      Miami by noon Friday. You won't be      able to reach me. When I see you      again, he'll be dead.
-- Asleep.
She won't wake up now.
I've been out there waiting for two hours.
Yeah?
It's open.
You took a chance coming here.
I didn't want to talk.     I just wanted to think.
Maybe we all did.
And what have you got?
It's not too late to back out.
What do you mean?
You don't think I can pull it off.
That's not what you really mean, is it, Matty?
No, it isn't. You think he's too much for me. You think I'll fuck it up, get us caught.
No? Well that's what I've been thinking.
It does in this world, the one we're living in.
When's he coming back?
That'll be it, then. Nothing will stop us.
Yeah.    I wasn't before, but I am now.
This time you're going to know how to reach me. I don't want any more surprises.
The cars at the end of the drive.
Fifteen minutes.
Uh -- no.     I don't think so.
I don't have them. I told you.
Get the hell out of here and don't come back.
Shh!
They're right on time and I'm running late.
We won't talk for a long time.
Who is he?
Hello.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes...    I see.
Uh-huh.    What problem is that?
No no, that would be all right.
I know of them.
Yes, I think so.
Right.
Will you get me Mrs. Edmund Walker, please.
I thought the temporary put her in.
Okay.    Try again later.
How are you?
No.   I don't. My condolences.
Mrs. Walker, I'm very sorry about your husband.
Hello, Peter.
Although it's certainly not required.
I'm confused, too. Do you have a problem with the witnessing or the signatures? What is it you're getting at?
In the state of Florida, when a person dies without a will, and there are no children and no surviving parents, then the spouse inherits everything.
You look good in black.
At first I couldn't figure out when you got ahold of my stationery and stuff. It finally came to me...
You've really done it, Matty.    You really have.
I hope you haven't done us in.
Hi, guys. Just come on in, make yourself at home.
Sorry, Oscar. Would you guys a beer?
It ain't great this time of day.
What do you mean?
What read in the paper. He died in the fire. Looks like arson--
Okay, was arson. You don't know if he was setting it and messed up...
His people owned the place or something?
They asked me to re-do the will. I met with her and Edmund. It was pretty simple. This Mary Ann Simpson witnessed it with me. Walker didn't seem to think it was any big deal.
That's it.
I don't know... old friend of theirs, good-looking broad. She was just passing through.
I suppose it's possible. I don't know much about her, except --
-- what I've seen. Wouldn't shock me, either way.
Well, I'm sorry, guys.    I'm afraid I can't do that.
First of all, did you get a look at her?
That wouldn't be quite so meaningful, except that today she started coming on to me. And maybe you haven't heard but the lady is about to come into a great deal of money.
The fact   is, she's invited me out to her place   tonight. And I'm going.
Peter, she's not gonna inherit anything by killing me.
They already think you're involved.
Great.
That's right.
I've been down there a lot lately.
Nooo. No, I'm not mad. Why should I be mad just because my friend here, who I've know for years, wants to know of my whereabouts on the night of our recent local murder?
That's my business!
So what?
Look, what is this? What do you want? Am I supposed to be an undercover agent for you guys, or something?
Are we done here?
I'll go out this way. I've had a lot of experience with disgruntled people.
I'll be over to Stella's, if you want to have some lunch.
Hello, Mrs. Kraft.
How are you making out?
You must be Heather.
I'm Ned Racine, Heather. I've heard a lot about you. It's nice to meet you.
I'm sorry our town is so hot for your visit.
Goodbye.
I'm fine, Stella. I'm fine.    What's the latest? Any hot news?
What's the special?
What day'd you cook 'em?
I don't know. I may have had my share for the day.
That's it?
Don't say that.     Don't say you don't have them.
They had to be here when you cleaned up that night. Think about it, think hard. They've probably got my prints on them.
So where could they have gone?
The housekeeper?
Where would she have put them?     You've been through his things.
That's crazy. You imagined it. I know, I've been imagining things, too. Plenty.
Don't you think we would have heard from her by now?
I'm sorry.
They've been stalling. They're draggin it out, hoping they'd come up with some way to implicate you.
Peter?
What are you doing here?
Yeah?
Nah. I'm going to Miami tomorrow.
I'm closing this real estate deal I've been working on.
Is this gonna be one of those conversations? Maybe I should have my lawyer present.
You're not known for being a hardliner.
Why is that?
Ned Racine.
Forget it.
Matty Walker?
When was this?
Did you tell her about the Gourson case?
Did you tell her about Gourson?
Just off the hook. What?
I'll find out.
He's good.
Thanks, Teddy.
Yeah.
Hello.
Okay. Where are you?
Tell me.
What's the best part?
Do you have them?
Yes.
In the boathouse.
Yes.
Hello, Matty.
In the back. With yours.
I could see.
Yes, it is.
It's Edmund's gun. You remember it, don't you?
I think you know.
It's the glasses, Matty.
I didn't see them.
Maybe I missed them. The way you missed them that night.
Keep talking, Matty. Experience shows I can be convinced of anything.
You never quit, do you? You just keep on coming.
The glasses, Matty. Why don't you go down there and get them?
I said I didn't see them.
No, Matty! Stop! Don't go in! Matty.
She's alive.
But what if that was someone else's body in there? What if it was already there when I got there -- dead and waiting for me. Maybe her friend...

You're not listening to me. What if she's been using this other girl's name? Since she met Walker three years ago, since she first spotted him and decided to take him... one way or another. Maybe Walker -- or any of us -- never knew her real name.
I don't know. Maybe there was something in her past, something so bad she was afraid it would queer it with Walker if he found out -- that he'd never marry her.
Let's say she's living as the other girl, this girl from her past. Someone whose history she knew and could use any way she wanted. And there's only one person in the world who knows the truth.

And then just when Matty's got me on the line, when she's finally going to collect, that one person shows up. That girl. Finds her. And threatens to expose her. So Matty starts paying her off. Maybe she even promises to cut her in on Edmunds' money. Now she's got to share it with two people.

But when Matty sees a way to get rid of both of them at once. A way to solve all her problems and get clear, with no one looking for her. At the boathouse. You find two bodies, me and this girl. Two killers dead.
You can't find the money, can you, Oscar? Doesn't that tell you something?
Oscar, don't you understand? That was her special gift she was relentless.
Matty was the kind of person who could do what was necessary. Whatever was necessary.
ever actually en route from Indiana or not. I think we're wasting our time here. It's pretty clear your client has attempted to defraud the county in a not very ingenious manner.
The Assistant Prosecutor has made what I consider a generous offer.

Yeah, yeah. If I were you, I'd recommend to your client that held quickly do as Mr. Lowenstein here has suggested -- plead nolo contendre, file Chapter Eleven and agree never to do business with Okeelanta County again.
He can walk. But don't test my patience for even five more minutes.
Mr. Racine. Next time you come into my courtroom I hope you've got either a better defense or a better class of client.
-- I think I've underestimated you, Ned. I don't know why it took me so long. You've started using your incompetence as a weapon.
He's an unhappy man, Thinks he should be Circuit Court by now. Here he is in a state with really top-notch corruption and he's stuck with the county toilets.
I'm surprised you weren't in on that toilet caper. Could have been that quick score you've always been searching for.
Maybe Stella was in on it.
Stella, when you gonna get a real air conditioner in here.
They don't have you. Gotta go.
You can't buy me. No sirree, I don't come cheap.
I had a dream last night that was so boring it woke me up. I was afraid to go back to sleep. Where the hell have you been?
I've barely seen you for a month.
You've never been shy about that stuff.
He's getting discreet. I can't believe it.
I'm really disappointed, Racine.
... And people are basically decent..
... Must be someone I know. Let's see -- someone in uniform...
...no Army personnel around.
I know, I know -- you finally got to Glenda.
How was it? Did she let you into the no parking zone?
A narc from Palm Beach? Is that his hobby?
Oscar, I just don't understand how you could be doing advanced theoretical thinking like that and still be stuck working in our little town.
Assistant County Prosecutor isn't the end for me, fellows.
my future in this state will be unlimited.
Hi, Ned.
I don't need my own. I'll just breathe the air.
Not me. The door was unlocked, inviting illegal entry. It's behavior like that makes Oscar's job so hard.
No thanks, I already had one.
Was arson.
It's not their style. They're very smooth. They'd rather destroy you than kill you. And they hate publicity.
Her sister-in-law's got plenty of ideas along that line, too. She could barely contain herself today, I could tell.
But she wants to wait and see how Matty treats her on the estate. She doesn't want to blow it.
I've got a feeling she's very bad news. Take some incredibly intelligent advice and stay away from her.
Ned, that lady may have just killed her husband.
He is mad.
It's not so recent anymore.   Maybe he's feeling some pressure.
Did you tell him about the glasses?
Seems Walker always ware glasses --
But there were none on the scene.
Interesting choice of phrase.
Hey, that's an idea. Ask her where the glasses are, where she did it...

Oh, yeah! Right, right. You'll love this, Ned, this latest development. Maybe you'll be able to work up a little sympathy for us, see why Oscar here has a tendency to get carried away. Tell him, Oscar.
Do you get it?    In the act or some fucking thing!
Oh, they're here. I ran into them on the way in. They're waiting outside.
The usual, my sweet.
Are you ready to hear something wild?
No, this is right up your alley.

Little Heather comes out onto the back porch, and this dude is out there with her aunt, see? And he's turned away with his pants or shorts or whatever dropped, so he's mooning the little girl, right. And he and your friend are going at something which Heather couldn't quite figure out.
Poor little Heather! She's never seen one angry before. But it made quite an impression on her.
One other thing. She says the guy's hair was greasy. He wore it slicked back. "Like a Cuban," she says. I loved that!
Can you imagine poor Heather? She hustled back to bed after getting a gander at that. And listen to why she got up in the first place, this is the capper. She had a nightmare!
Hi, Ned.
I've been looking for you.
Yeah.    You always run this late?
What's in Miami?
You're some kind of health nut.
Matty Walker smokes that same brand.
Buddy, your lawyer is present.
You know, that Edmund Walker was a bad guy. The more I find out about him, the happier I am he's dead. I figure it's a positive thing for the world.
Mmm. I have my own standards. I try to keep them private.
As far as I'm concerned, I don't care who killed him. And I don't care who gets rich because of it.
But Oscar, Oscar's not like that.
Oscar's unhappy right now. He's in pain.
Because he likes you. He likes you even better than I do.
That's why he's been busting his butt trying to locate this Mary Ann Simpson. They finally found her place in Miami yesterday, but the woman herself was gone... looked like she left in a hurry.
Oscar thought any story she could tell might help you. He thinks you need help.

Someone's putting you in deep trouble, my friend. From about three thirty to five AM on the night Walker was killed, someone called your hotel room repeatedly. The hotel didn't want to put them through, but whoever was calling convinced them it was an emergency. The phone rang and rang, but you didn't answer.
Don't say anything. Save it for some Other time. It gets worse.
Now someone's trying to give us Edmund's glasses. We don't know who.
I wish I knew what to tell you, Ned.
I'll see ya.
Stupid. That's always been the problem.
Her mind encompasses his.
What's the word from the hallowed halls of justice? Anything juicy?
You don't like it there's lots of other places.
Why does he do that?
Did you hear about Dr. Block?
Agnes Marshall.
It was! How'd you know? Christ, you're plugged in better than me.
It's the heat.
Cherry, cherry... and cherry.
I like the cherry.
I'll have you know Glenda is seriously involved with a narc from Palm Beach.
It's true. I could tell you some people who'll be dead if we don't get a break soon.
Hi, Racine. How you doing today?
Nothing much doing. What'll it be?
Veal outlets.
They're fresh this month.
Two ice teas for Fred Astaire.
I'm a married woman.
Meaning I'm not looking for company.
That's my business.
How happy I am.
You're not too smart, are you?
I like that in a man.
You don't look lazy.
Tell me, does chat like that work with most women?
I wondered. Thought maybe I was out of touch.
I told you. I've got a husband.
He's out of town.
He only comes up on the weekends.
You want to buy me something?   I'll take one of these.
Cherry.
Is this town that small?
How'd you know?
How does Pinehaven look?
Yes, I'm well tended, all right.
Get married.
Good.    Nice move, Matty.
At least it's cool. I'm burning up.
Would you get me a paper towel or something? Dip it in some cold water.
You don't want to lick it?
Look who's here. Isn't this a coincidence?
You're the one that doesn't want to talk about the heat. Too bad. I'd tell you about my chimes.
The wind chimes on my porch. They keep ringing and I go out there expecting a cool breeze. That's what they've always meant. But not this summer, This summer it's just hot air.
What are you doing in Pinehaven?
There are some men, once they get a whiff of it, they'll trail you like a hound.
What is your name, anyway?
Matty Walker.
Yes. My temperature runs a couple degrees high. Around 100 all the time I don't mind it. It's the engine or something.
Don't tell me -- you have just the right tool.
How'd you find me, Ned?
How'd you know I drink?
You shouldn't have come. You're going to be disappointed.
A lot of them have tried that seat.
Most men are little boys.
Too quiet.
This is a blouse and a skirt. I don't know what you're talking about.
I don't like my body much.   It's never been right.
Sometimes, I don't know. I get so sick of everything, I'm not sure I care anymore. Do you know what I mean, Ned?
Yeah, that's what I mean.
I think I'll get out of here now.
I have a car.
You want to see the chimes.
That's all.   If I let you, that's all.
I mean it. I like you.    But my life is complicated enough.
This is my community bar. I might have to come here with my husband some time. Would you leave before me?  Wait in your car? I know it seems silly...
Now leave me alone.
Remember your promise.
She goes home nights.
No.
Boat house.
Boat.
It's a mess. There's a row boat, a lot of lounge chairs... things like that.
I think you should go now.
You've seen them. Please go.
Yes, I did. I said what I meant.
Yes... Please.
There is for me.
Thank you. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have lot you come.
No...    I'm weak.
Yes, yes...
Please, please ...
I didn't want this to happen. But I didn't try hard enough to stop it...
You were on top.
Yes sir.
It's your fault.
Are you sure?    I just want to make sure here.
No, you misunderstood --
-- this is my new saddle, and I just want to --
I've got to wash these.
That's right. My mother told me "knowledge is power."
No one must know. Promise me, Ned.
Ned, this is Mary Ann.
Do you want to stay for dinner?
Mary Ann's an old friend. She's like a sister to me. She wants me to be happy.
What sin?
Not even a Mercedes?
With genuine calf skin upholstery?
Not this?
Is there any more ice?   I'm burning up.
He's coming up tomorrow.
I can't stand the thought of him...
Just do what I say! Go into the living room.
I'm going to make it up to you tonight. But you must behave.      Now go!
Good.
Good evening, sir... welcome to...
Don't you like it?
You don't like it? I thought you went for this stuff.
Wait ...   wait ... I want to tell you about the   thing... the thing that will drop   from the ceiling... in case the   cabin suddenly depressurizes --
What are we doing here?
I want to be in bed.

Yes ... that's all I ever think about ... You and me. Your body near mine, close. I'm not right when you're not with me. I get the shakes. And each time, when I first see you, I shake even more. For a while. And then I get calm. I feel safe ...
Don't say it, if you don't mean it.
I'm going to tell Edmund I want a divorce. I won't stay any longer. I would have, if you hadn't come along.
He got   what he wanted... he has a knack   for that. But no more. I'm ready   to walk away from the money.
Oh, I know you will, darling. I didn't mean that. I know you will. But it doesn't matter. It's you I want.
Of the divorce?
No.   I signed a pre-nuptial agreement.
He insisted. He blamed it on his sister Roz -- she's always hated me --
Bad. I get some money for a year.
Does it matter, Ned? Tell me the truth please. I'll understand, I swear to you.
God, you've made me happy.
It's time for your present.
From now on, when it starts coming down on you, I'll be there to protect you.
Put it on! I'll bet I guessed the size right.
I love it.
Look in my eyes. Can you see yourself?
Here!
Come to me.
No... I couldn't.
I saw the will once. He showed it to me. He was trying to prove something ... how much he loved me or something.
The stock market, investments, real estate. He doesn't tell me anything, but I've picked up a little. I know they own a lot of land along the shore here.
He's never introduced me to anyone.
They own that old place in Miranda Beach, The Breakers... I know that.
Edmund mentioned it once.
Ned, it scares me to talk about these things.
You know.
Let's just not, okay? Let's not think about all he's got.
I'm afraid... because when I think about it, I wish that he'd die. That's really what I want. It's horrible and ugly and It's what I most want.
What do you mean?
Don't talk about it, Ned. Please don't. Talk is dangerous. Sometimes it makes things happen, it makes it real.
I'm afraid, Ned.
Hello.
Darling, I'd like you to meet Mr.
Mr. Racine is the lawyer I told you about.
You remember. He had a client who wanted to buy the house. I told him we weren't selling.
Edmund, really.     It's Mr. Racine's profession.
Edmund's company owns The Breakers.
I'm too dumb. Woman, you know.
I'll be right back.
I waited till I saw her leave.      Please don't be angry with me.
It didn't lock. Oh. Ned, hold me.
He left this morning.      I had to see you.
I couldn't call. I'm afraid to call.
I'm careful. I hated it, Ned. I hated sitting there with the two of you. I thought I was going to scream.
No, never.
I went to phone booths. I'm afraid of him, Ned. I'm always afraid.
Why, Ned, why do you say this now?

It's a small thing, but it's the law. It forbids an inheritance to be passed down indefinitely for generations. Many general practitioner lawyers don't fully understand it. It doesn't come up much for them, because wills this complex are usually handled by estate departments in larger firms. Handled by lawyers who specialize in this type of work.
